summary: health-care providers and health departments across the united states should be prepared to consider, detect, and manage cases of MERS. no specific treatment for MERS-CoV infection is currently available. additional guidance for health-care providers is available at http://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/mers/interim-guidance.html. infection control HCP should adhere to recommended infection-control measures, including standard, contact, and airborne precautions. nasopharyngeal swab, oropharyngeal swab, sputum, serum, and stool/rectal swab are recommended for suspected MERS cases. nasopharyngeal/oropharyngeal specimens can be placed in the same tube of viral transport medium as nasopharyngeal swabs. CDC recommends all travelers to countries in or near the Arabian Peninsula protect themselves from respiratory diseases, including MERS. if travelers to the region have onset of fever with cough or shortness of breath during their trip, they should seek medical care. if travelers to the region have onset of fever with cough or shortness of breath during their trip, they should seek medical care. additional guidance for health-care providers is available at http://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/mers/interim-guidance.html. infection control HCP should adhere to recommended infection-control measures, including standard, contact, and airborne precautions. nasopharyngeal swab, oropharyngeal swab, sputum, serum, and stool/rectal swab should be collected for submission to CDC or the appropriate public health laboratory. personnel collecting specimens should wear recommended personal protective equipment (i.e., gloves, gowns, eye protection, and respiratory protection) countries in or near the Arabian Peninsula protect themselves from respiratory diseases, including MERS. travelers should call ahead to their health-care provider and mention their recent travel. CDC is using partner distribution lists, e-mail subscription channels, social media, and airport messages to alert travelers about precautions for MERS.
